sub_concepts.name: Contour lines
sub_concepts.definition: Contour lines are lines on a map that connect points of equal elevation, helping to visualize the shape and slope of the terrain.

sub_concepts.name: Scale
sub_concepts.definition: Scale on a topographic map shows the relationship between distance on the map and distance in the real world, usually expressed as a representative fraction or a bar scale.

sub_concepts.name: Symbols
sub_concepts.definition: Topographic maps use standardized symbols to represent various features like buildings, roads, rivers, and vegetation, allowing users to quickly understand the map.

sub_concepts.name: Gradient
sub_concepts.definition: Gradient in the context of topographic maps refers to the rate of change in elevation, often conveyed through the closeness of contour lines or color shading.

sub_concepts.name: Relief
sub_concepts.definition: Relief on a topographic map is the difference in height between various points on the map, often visualized using shading, hypsometric tints, or exaggerated vertical relief.

sub_concepts.name: Grid system
sub_concepts.definition: A grid system on a topographic map is a network of intersecting lines, usually at right angles, that help users determine coordinates and locate features precisely.

sub_concepts.name: Map key
sub_concepts.definition: The map key, or legend, on a topographic map explains the meaning of the symbols, lines, and colors used on the map, allowing users to interpret the map correctly.

sub_concepts.name: Hydrography
sub_concepts.definition: Hydrography on a topographic map includes the depiction of water features like rivers, lakes, and wetlands, as well as underwater features like contour intervals and depth curves.
